subject: Medicine
title: Receptors: The Lock and Key
description: A quick, practical guide to Receptors: The Lock and Key.

hook.text: Most drugs work by fitting into a protein on your cells like a key in a lock. The fit determines the effect.

buildup.text: Receptors are proteins on cell surfaces or inside cells that respond to specific molecules.

discovery.text: Agonists activate the receptor like a key turning a lock. Antagonists block it like a key that fits but won't turn.

twist.text: Many drug side effects occur because the drug fits receptors it wasn't designed forâ€”off-target binding.

climax.text: The more precisely a drug targets one receptor, the fewer side effects and the better the treatment.

punchline.text: The perfect drug fits one lock and no others.

quiz.question: What is the difference between an agonist and an antagonist?
options: Agonists activate receptors; antagonists block them
Agonists are natural; antagonists are synthetic
Agonists cause side effects; antagonists are always safe
